verses.verse: And [Jesus] went into and passed through Jericho.
And look, there was a man named Zacchaeus, who was the chief tax collector, and he was rich.
He wanted to see Jesus, what he was like, but he couldn't, because of the crowd and because he was short.
He ran ahead and climbed into a sycamore tree to see him, for he was going to pass that way.
When Jesus came to that place, he looked up, saw him, and said to him, "Zacchaeus, be quick and come down, for I must stay at your house today."
He quickly came down and welcomed him joyfully.
When they saw [it], they all complained, saying, that he was going to be a guest with a man who is a sinner.
Zacchaeus stood and said to the Lord, "Behold, Lord, I give half of my goods to the poor, and if I have taken anything from any man by false accusation, I restore [to him] fourfold."
Jesus said to him, "This day salvation has come to this house, for he is also a son of Abraham.
"For the Son of Man has come to seek and to save the lost."
While listening to this, he added and spoke a parable, because he was near Jerusalem and because they thought that the Kingdom of God should immediately appear.
And so he said, "A certain noble man went into a distant country to receive a kingdom for himself and to return.
"He called his ten servants, gave them ten minas, and said to them, «Do business until I come.»
"But his citizens hated him and sent a message to him saying, «We do not want this [man] to reign over us.»

"And so it happen that when he returned after he received the kingdom, he then commanded these servants to be called to him whom he had given the money, so that he could know how much every man had gained in business.
"Then the first came saying, «Lord, your mina has increased to ten minas.»
"And he said to him, «Well done, you good servant. Because you have been faithful in very little you will have authority over ten cities.»
"The second came saying, «Lord, your mina has increased to five minas.»
"And he said to him similarly, «You also rule of five cities.»
"And another came saying, «Lord, look [here is] your mina which I have laid aside in a piece of cloth,
for I was afraid of you because you are a harsh man. You take what you haven't put down and reap what you didn't sow.»
"And he said to him, «I will judge you by your own words of your mouth, you wicked servant. You know that I was a harsh man taking up what I don't put down and reaping what I didn't sow.
"Why didn't you then put my money in the bank, that at my coming back I could have received my own with interest.'
"And he said to those who stood close, «Take the mina from him and give it to him who has ten minas.»
"(And they said to him, «Lord, he has ten minas.»)
"For I say to you that to every one who has, will be given, and from him who doesn't have, even what he does have will be taken away from him.
"But my enemies who didn't want me to reign over them, bring them here and slay them in front of me."
After he had spoken this, he went forward going to Jerusalem.
And so it happened when he was near Bethphage and Bethany at the mount called the Mount of Olives, he sent two of his disciples.
He said, "Go into the village in front of you. When you enter you will find a colt tied on which no one has even sat on; loosen him and bring [him here].
"If any one asks you, «Why are you untying him?» Say this to him, «Because the Lord has need of him.»
Those who were sent, found just as he had said to them.
As they were untying the colt, its owners said to them, «Why are you untying the colt?»
They said, "The Lord has need of him."
They brought him to Jesus, placed their outer garments on the colt, and set Jesus on it.
As he went, they spread their clothes on the road.
When he had now come near at the descent from the Mount of Olives, the whole crowd of the disciples started to rejoice and praise God with a loud voice for all the mighty works that they had seen.
They said, "Blessed be the King who comes in the name of the Lord. Peace in heaven and glory in the highest."
Some of the Pharisees among the crowd said to him, "Master, rebuke your disciples."
He answered and said to them, "I tell you that if these would be quiet, then the stones would immediately shout."
When he had come near, he saw the city and wept over it,
saying, "If you had known, even you, at least in this your day, the things [which are] for your peace, but now they are hidden from your eyes.
"For the days will come to you that your enemies will dig a trench around you and surround you and isolate you completely.
"They will level you to the ground and your children with you. They will not leave in you one stone on another, because you didn't know the time of your visitation."
He went into the temple and started to throw out those who sold in it and those who bought.
He said to them, "It is written: «My house is the house of prayer,» but you have made it a den of thieves."
He taught daily in the temple. The chief priests, the scribes, and the high ranking people looked for ways to kill him.
They could not find a way to do it, for all the people were very attentive to hear him.
